Executive Summary for Cordova Energy Company Risk Management Plan

Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies
Cordova Energy Company is strongly committed to employee, public and environmental safety.  The commitment is demonstrated by an accidental release program that covers areas such as design, installation, operating procedures, maintenance, and employee training associated with processes at the facility.  It is our policy to implement appropriate controls to prevent potential releases of regulated substances.

The Facility and Regulated Processes
Cordova Energy Company's primary activity is the generation of electric energy by combustion of natural gas.  Part of that activity involves the use of a system that provides aqueous ammonia for selective catalytic reduction (SCR) in the heat recovery steam generators.  The aqueous ammonia storage and forwarding system (the process) consists of a storage tank, two forwarding pumps, associated piping, valves, and instrumentation.  Atomized ammonia is sprayed on to the SCR section.  The flue gas entrains the ammonia and as the mixture passes through the SCR, it undergoes a reaction that reduces nitrogen oxides to meet environmental regulatory requirements.

The maximum inventory of aqueous ammonia in the process is 50,000 gallons (370,000 pounds).  In the storage tank, ammonia is concentrated at 29% in water.

We determined that there are no public receptors within the worst-case or alternative release scenarios and there is no history of releases of regulated substances.  Therefore, this process qualifies for Program Level 1.  The off site consesquence analysis performed as part of this re-submittal was completed using EPA's RMP*Comp(TM) software.  

General Accidental Release Prevention Program and Chemical-Specific Prevention Steps
The facility has taken all the necessary steps to comply with the accidental release prevention requirements set out under 40 CFR Part 68 for Program Level 1 processes.

The facility was designed and constructed in accordance with appropriate engineering and nationally recognized design standards.  The following sections describe the elements of the release prevention program that is in place.

Process Safety Information
In accordance with 40 CFR 68.48, Cordova Energy Company maintains detailed records of safety information that describes chemical hazards, operating parameters, and equipment designs associated with the regulated process.  Records include
* material safety data sheets, 
* maximum intended inventory of equipment in which aqueous ammonia is stored, 
* safe upper and lower temperatures, pressures, flows and compositions,
* equipment specifications, and
* codes and standards used to design, build, and operate the process.
The process has been designed in compliance with recognized and generally accepted good engineering practices.   Safety information will be periodically reviewed to ensure that it is accurate.

Process Hazard Analysis
In accordance with 40 CFR 68.50, Cordova Energy Company has conducted a review of the hazards associated with aqueous ammonia, so that controls can be implemented, as necessary.  The methodology used includes checklists and a planned 5-year review by qualified engineering personnel.  The review identifies
* any hazards associated with the process and ammonia,
* opportunities for equipment malfunctions or human errors that could result in an accidental release,
* safeguards used or needed to control the hazards or prevent equipment malfunction or human error, and
* steps used or needed to detect or monitor releases.

An initial hazard review was performed prior to process startup.  An additional hazard review was completed as part of this re-submittal.  The results of each review have been documented to ensure that any problems identified are resolved in a timely manner.

Operating Procedures
For the purpose of safely conducting activities within the process, Cordova Energy Company maintai

ns written operating procedures in compliance with 40 CFR 68.52.  These procedures address various modes of operation such as startup, normal operations, emergency shutdown, inspections and emergency operations.  The information is regularly reviewed and is readily accessible to operators involved in the process.

Training
In accordance with 40 CFR 68.54, Cordova Energy Company has a comprehensive training program in place to ensure that employees who are operating the process are competent in the operating procedures associated with the process.  The training program provides for refresher training at least every three years and more frequently, as needed.

Maintenance
In accordance with 40 CFR 68.56, Cordova Energy Company carries out documented maintenance checks on process equipment to ensure proper operation.  Process equipment examined by these checks includes ammonia forwarding pumps, storage tank, dilution air fans, heaters, ammonia detectors, associated piping and instrumentation.  Maintenance operations are carried out by qualified personnel with previous training in maintenance practices.  Furthermore, these personnel are offered specialized training as needed.  Any equipment deficiencies identified by the maintenance checks are corrected in a safe and timely manner. 

Management of Change
Written procedures are in place to manage changes in process chemicals, technology and procedures.  Reviews of maintenance procedures are performed routinely and documented in the operating record.  Process operators, maintenance personnel and other employees whose job tasks are affected by a modification in process conditions are promptly made aware of and offered training to deal with the modification.

Pre-Startup Reviews
Pre-startup safety reviews related to new processes and to modifications in established processes are conducted as a regular practice. These reviews are conducted to confirm that construction, equipment, operating and maintenance procedures are suit

able for safe startup prior to placing equipment into operation.

Compliance Audits
In compliance with 40 CFR 68.58, Cordova Energy Company conducts compliance audits at least every three years to determine whether the provisions set out under the RMP rule are being implemented.  These audits are to be conducted by persons knowledgeable in the process.  Corrective actions required as a result of the audits will be documented to assure that they are undertaken in a safe and prompt manner.  Compliance audit reports will be maintained for a minimum of five years.

Incident Investigation
In accordance with 40 CFR 68.60, Cordova Energy Company will promptly investigate any accident that has resulted in, or could reasonably result in, a reportable release of a regulated substance.  These investigations will be undertaken to identify the situation leading to the incident as well as any corrective actions to prevent the release from reoccurring.  Investigation summaries will be maintained for a minimum of five years.

Employee Participation
Cordova Energy Company believes that process safety management and accident prevention is a team effort.  Company employees are strongly encouraged to express their views concerning accident prevention issues and to recommend improvements.  In addition, our employees have access to all information created as part of the facility's implementation of the RMP rule, including information resulting from process hazard analyses.

Contractors
On occasion, our company hires contractors to conduct specialized maintenance and construction activities.  Prior to selecting a contractor, a thorough evaluation of safety performance of the contractor is carried out.   Cordova Energy Company has a strict policy of informing the contractors of potential hazards related to the contractor's work and the processes.  Contractors are also informed of all the procedures for emergency response should an accidental release of a regulated substance occur. 

Emerge

ncy Response Plan
Cordova Energy Company has developed a written emergency response plan to deal with accidental releases of hazardous materials.  The plan includes aspects of emergency response including notifications of local emergency response agencies and the public, first aid and medical treatment, evacuations, and post-incident decontamination of infected areas.  We do not maintain an emergency response capability within the facility for major incidents; the emergency response plan calls for notification of outside assistance in dealing with hazardous materials incidents.

To insure proper functioning, our release detection, routine monitoring and emergency equipment is regularly inspected and serviced.  Also, the emergency response plan is routinely reviewed and updated as necessary to reflect pertinent changes taking place within the processes that would require amended emergency response measures.

Our emergency plan is coordinated with the The Rock Island County Emergency Services and Disaster Agency (the Local Emergency Planning Committee or LEPC) and the Village of Cordova Fire Department.  The telephone number of the LEPC is (309) 799-5166.

Five-Year Accident History
There is no history of accidents at the Cordova Energy Company.
